## The GOT Marriage Dataset

### Reading in data


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
got_marriages <- read_csv("_data/got/got_marriages.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)
```
:::


### IGraph from Edgelist

This edgelist comes with edge attributes `Type`, `Notes` and `Generation`.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Directed = FALSE because marriages are intrinsically symmetric:
got_marriages.net <- graph_from_data_frame(got_marriages,
                                           directed = FALSE)
got_marriages.net
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

+ attr: name (v/c), Type (e/c), Notes (e/c), Generation (e/c)
+ edges from f19023a (vertex names):

 [4] Martell  --Essos       Martell  --Reach       Martell  --Essos
```

:::
:::


These are the vertexes (nodes). They represent a blend of land areas, administrative zones, and family Houses:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
V(got_marriages.net)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
+ 20/20 vertices, named, from f19023a:
 [1] Targaryen   Baratheon   Martell     Lannister   Tyrell      Reach      
 [7] North       Riverlands  Westerlands Stark       Vale        Arryn      
[13] Tully       Frey        Crownlands  Stormlands  Essos       Septa      
[19] Dorne       Beyond Wall
```
:::
:::

These are the types of edges we have:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
unique(E(got_marriages.net)$Type)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] "Married" "Engaged" "Affair" 
```
:::
:::



#### Plot

The most basic plot. Binary weight.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(got_marriages.net,
            arrow.mode="-")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](steveoneill_week2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

Here we add each marriage relationship, including affairs, to the `weight` value which has meaning to the `igraph` package


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
E(got_marriages.net)$weight<-E(got_marriages.net)$Type
```
:::


After `weight` has been added, the graph looks much different:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(got_marriages.net,
            arrow.mode="-")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
Warning in (function (graph, coords = NULL, dim = 2, niter = 500, start.temp =
sqrt(vcount(graph)), : NAs introduced by coercion
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](steveoneill_week2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

I want to have colors for these specific marriage types:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
#Define colors for each type of marriage
colors <- c(Married = "red", 
            Engaged = "green", 
            Affair = "blue")

#Match() matches "Married" with "red", and so on
E(got_marriages.net)$color <- colors[match(E(got_marriages.net)$Type, names(colors))]

plot(got_marriages.net,
     arrow.mode="-",
     edge.color=E(got_marriages.net)$color,
     main="Game of Thrones Marriage Network",
     sub="Edges colored by type of marriage"
    )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
Warning in (function (graph, coords = NULL, dim = 2, niter = 500, start.temp =
sqrt(vcount(graph)), : NAs introduced by coercion
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
legend("bottomleft", legend=c("Married", "Engaged", "Affair"), fill=colors, title="Type of marriage", cex=0.8)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](steveoneill_week2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


Here is an alternative, circular layout that in my opinion is not as useful because it does not highlight the isolation of `Beyond Wall`:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
layout1 <- layout_in_circle(got_marriages.net)

plot(got_marriages.net,
     arrow.mode="-",
     edge.color=E(got_marriages.net)$color,
     edge.width=1,
     main="Game of Thrones Marriage Network",
     sub="Edges colored by type of marriage",
     layout = layout1
     )
legend("bottomleft", legend=c("Married", "Engaged", "Affair"), fill=colors, title="Type of marriage", cex=0.8)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](steveoneill_week2_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::
